content:
I would love to get my hands on this book, but it seems to be out of print. Is there an electronic version floating around somewhere? Any ideas how to get it?

Edit: I miss the UIUC library :blush:

PS: Btw, I am reading this

https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.pjm/1102650385

and could really use some help if this stuff is of interest to anyone here :blush:
In case it helps someone be interested: there's a forgetful functor from differential graded algebras to algebras, and the paper is studying things similar to the left adjoint of this functor.
I'm looking for more information about what they refer to as "Karoubi differential envelope"

For example at the top of page 249 they're looking at the left adjoint of the forgetful functor from Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2-graded differential algebras to Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2-graded algebras. They don't say "left adjoint" but buzzwords like "universal property", and the commutative triangle, give it away.

John, that sounds cool :blush:

Yeah, one way to say it is that I am trying to understand the functor from algebras to differential graded algebras.

The "Karoubi differential envelope", if I remember it correctly, is the left adjoint of the forgetful functor from differential graded algebras (and I mean ordinary N\mathbb{N}N-graded algebras) to algebras.
I used to be really into this stuff in grad school, when noncommutative geometry was sorta new.
There is also (I think) a related functor (or something) from directed graphs to DGAs.

There are well-known functors from

  • directed graphs

to

  • simplicial sets

to

  • differential graded vector spaces

to

  • differential graded algebras

so we can compose those.
A universal first-order differential calculus corresponds to a complete graph.
(I easily get myself in trouble throwing around words like "universal" especially here :sweat_smile: )

I'm also looking at:

Differential Calculi on Commutative Algebras

I call a differential calculus arising from a directed graph a "discrete calculus".

So I'd say something like, "A discrete calculus is obtained from the universal discrete calculus by removing edges from the complete graph."
This is explained in Introduction to Noncommutative Geometry of Commutative Algebras and Applications in Physics

So I am basically trying to link up Muller-Hoissen's paper to Coquereaux and Kastler paper, but there seems to be some inconsistency between the two I'm trying to sort out and hoping this reference will help :pray:

John Baez said:

The "Karoubi differential envelope", if I remember it correctly, is the left adjoint of the forgetful functor from differential graded algebras (and I mean ordinary N\mathbb{N}N-graded algebras) to algebras.

Any idea where I can read about U: DGAlg -> Alg or is it trivial enough to state here? I hope it isn't just "forgetting the grade" :blush:
Would it be simply projecting to grade 0?
I guess there are a couple functors from DGAlg to Alg, as you mention: forgetting the grading and differential, or taking the degree-zero part.

Let me think about which one is right adjoint to the following functor F: Alg -> DGAlg:

the functor that takes an algebra A, decrees everything in it is of degree 0, and freely throws in a differential d that increases the degree by one and obeys all all the differential graded algebra rules.
So say we want a functor U: DGAlg -> Alg that's right adjoint to this F.

I.e. given an algebra A and a differential graded algebra B we want dga homomorphisms

f: FA -> B

to correspond naturally algebra homomorphisms

g: A -> UB

Note that f: FA -> B is completely determined by what it does to guys of degree zero, since we can write everything in FA as a linear combination of guys of this form:

a da' da'' da''' ...

i.e. a product of a guy in A and a finite number of differentials of guys in A,

and f of such a product must be

f(a) d(f(a')) d(f(a'')) d(f(a''')) ...
Since f preserves the degree, it's determined by some algebra homomorphism g: A -> UB where UB is the degree zero part of B.

Furthermore I claim any algebra homomorphism g: A -> UB extends to some dga homomorphism f: FA -> B by the formula above, or more precisely

f( a da' da'' ... ) = g(a) d(g(a')) d(g(a'')) ...
So, if all this is right, the right adjoint U: DGAlg -> Alg takes the degree-zero part of a dga, and the left adjoint F: Alg -> DGAlg freely creates a dga whose degree-zero part is the given algebra.
All this is standard stuff... easier to figure out than to look up!
The discipline of adjoint functors is a way to make sure one isn't just randomly making stuff up.

:heart: :raised_hands:

That is so beautiful :heart_eyes:

I wish I could just see things so clear like that.

The discipline of adjoint functors is a way to make sure one isn't just randomly making stuff up.

Yes. Totally. That is one reason I "try" to bring CT into the picture because I can build models and even write code to verify that it works, but it sometimes feels shaky withouy some nice maths to bring it together.
Thank you :raised_hands:

If I understand, the stuff in Kastler's papers is explicity constructing the functor F:Alg→DGAlgF: \text{Alg} \to \text{DGAlg}F:Alg→DGAlg, but the details include actually constructing ddd from AAA as well.

Referring back to the article that references this book (that I'd like to get my hands on), I think I understand how d:A→Jd:A\to Jd:A→J is constructed (when AAA is unital), but then it says

Since ddd uniquely extends to a differential ddd of ΩA\Omega AΩA (i.e. a ∂\partial∂-graded derivation of vanishing square), moreover of N\mathbb{N}N-grade 1, ΩA\Omega AΩA becomes a Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2-graded (in fact a bigraded) differential algebra.

Unfortunately, it isn't obvious to me how to explicity construct

d:Jn→Jn+1d: J^n \to J^{n+1}d:Jn→Jn+1

and I need that explicit construction if I am going to turn that into some code and generate numerical results.

Since U:DGAlg→AlgU: \text{DGAlg}\to \text{Alg}U:DGAlg→Alg is so simple, is there a way to make F:Alg→DGAlgF: \text{Alg}\to\text{DGAlg}F:Alg→DGAlg 100% explicit (as in I can write code and compute stuff) at least when AAA is finite dimensional and commutative?

Now, I "think" this construction produces a universal DGA, i.e.

A↦FΩ~AA \overset{F}{\mapsto}\tilde\Omega AA↦F​Ω~A

where Ω~A\tilde\Omega AΩ~A is universal so I'd still need some explicit way to obtain other DGAs once we have the universal DGA, but I'd be super happy to get to the universal DGA explicitly as a start.

Btw, if AAA is finite-dimensional with basis elements eie^iei and product eiej=δi,jeie^i e^j = \delta^{i,j}e^ieiej=δi,jei, then the unit is just

1=∑iei 1 = \sum_i e^i1=∑i​ei

and

a=∑ia(i)ei.a = \sum_i a(i) e^i.a=∑i​a(i)ei.

The map

d:A→Jd: A\to Jd:A→J

is given explicity by C&K as

da=1⊗a−(−1)∣a∣a⊗1.da = 1\otimes a - (-1)^{|a|} a\otimes 1.da=1⊗a−(−1)∣a∣a⊗1.

However, this can be written as a graded commutator

da=1⊗a−(−1)∣a∣a⊗1=(1⊗1)a−(−1)∣a∣a(1⊗1)=[G,a],\begin{aligned}da &= 1\otimes a - (-1)^{|a|} a\otimes 1\\&= (1\otimes 1)a - (-1)^{|a|} a(1\otimes 1) \\ &= [G,a],\end{aligned}da​=1⊗a−(−1)∣a∣a⊗1=(1⊗1)a−(−1)∣a∣a(1⊗1)=[G,a],​

where

G=1⊗1=∑i,jei⊗ej.\begin{aligned} G &= 1\otimes 1 \\ &= \sum_{i,j} e^i\otimes e^j.\end{aligned}G​=1⊗1=i,j∑​ei⊗ej.​

Now, if we interpret eie^iei as (dual to) vertices and ei⊗eje^i\otimes e^jei⊗ej as (dual to) directed edges from iii to jjj of a directed graph, then GGG is related to the adjacency matrix of a complete directed graph.

So we should have some natural way to go from

DiGraph→DGAlg\text{DiGraph}\to \text{DGAlg}DiGraph→DGAlg

that is closely related to the above.

Eric Forgy said:

Referring back to the article that references this book (that I'd like to get my hands on), I think I understand how d:A→Jd:A\to Jd:A→J is constructed (when AAA is unital), but then it says

Since ddd uniquely extends to a differential ddd of ΩA\Omega AΩA (i.e. a ∂\partial∂-graded derivation of vanishing square), moreover of N\mathbb{N}N-grade 1, ΩA\Omega AΩA becomes a Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2-graded (in fact a bigraded) differential algebra.

Unfortunately, it isn't obvious to me how to explicity construct

d:Jn→Jn+1d: J^n \to J^{n+1}d:Jn→Jn+1

and I need that explicit construction if I am going to turn that into some code and generate numerical results.

Is JnJ^nJn your notation for the things of grade nnn in ΩA\Omega AΩA?

I don't want to worry about the bigraded stuff now; I'd rather talk about an associative algebra AAA and the free dga on that algebra, which I'd probably call ΩA\Omega AΩA - but in case Kastler means something really different by that I'll call it FAFAFA for now.

Since U:DGAlg→AlgU: \text{DGAlg}\to \text{Alg}U:DGAlg→Alg is so simple, is there a way to make F:Alg→DGAlgF: \text{Alg}\to\text{DGAlg}F:Alg→DGAlg 100% explicit (as in I can write code and compute stuff) at least when AAA is finite dimensional and commutative?

FAFAFA is pretty explicit. First, note that every grade-nnn element of FAFAFA is a linear combination of guys like

a0da1⋯dana_0 da_1 \cdots da_n a0​da1​⋯dan​

It takes a bit of work to see this because if you freely start multiplying things you get more complicated expressions like

a0(da1)b1(da2)b2⋯(dan)bn a_0 (da_1) b_1 (da_2) b_2 \cdots (da_n) b_n a0​(da1​)b1​(da2​)b2​⋯(dan​)bn​

So how can we get rid of all these b's? The trick is to remember that we're requiring

d(ab)=(da)b+a(db) d(ab) = (da)b + a(db) d(ab)=(da)b+a(db)

so

(da)b=d(ab)−a(db) (da)b = d(ab) - a(db)(da)b=d(ab)−a(db)

gives a recipe for taking dadada multiplied on the right by bbb and turning it into a difference of two terms of the form dxdxdx multiplied by something on the left:

(da)b=1d(ab)−a(db) (da)b = 1 d(ab) - a(db)(da)b=1d(ab)−a(db)

Repeatedly using this rule we can take

a0(da1)b1(da2)b2⋯(dan)bn a_0 (da_1) b_1 (da_2) b_2 \cdots (da_n) b_n a0​(da1​)b1​(da2​)b2​⋯(dan​)bn​

and show it's equal to a linear combination of terms of the form

x0dx1⋯dxnx_0 dx_1 \cdots dx_n x0​dx1​⋯dxn​

where the x's are elements of AAA depending on the a's and b's in some way.

Anyway, once you know this it's easy to say what ddd does:

d(x0dx1⋯dxn)=dx0dx1⋯dxn d(x_0 dx_1 \cdots dx_n) = dx_0 dx_1 \cdots dx_nd(x0​dx1​⋯dxn​)=dx0​dx1​⋯dxn​
But this is not magic, or cleverness! It just follows from the rules of a dga: repeatedly use d2=0d^2 = 0d2=0 and d(xy)=(dx)y+xdyd(xy) = (dx)y + x dyd(xy)=(dx)y+xdy.
Indeed, everything about the free dga FAFAFA follows from the rules of a dga, the rules for adding and multiplying elements of AAA, and nothing more. That's what "free" means, in practice.
So if you know how to compute in AAA, you know - after some thought - how to compute in FAFAFA.

Thank you John :heart: :raised_hands:

I totally get what you mean about moving everything to the left (or right) etc using the product rule :+1:

It is not a mathematical problem, but I prefer to not leave a differential exposed directly on either the left or right side like that though (but I get what you mean) so I'd say write linear combinations of elements like

x0dx1⋯dxnxn.x_0 dx_1 \cdots dx_n x_n.x0​dx1​⋯dxn​xn​.

To see why, consider a finite (commutative) algebra with bases eie^iei, product eiej=δi,jeie^i e^j = \delta^{i,j} e^ieiej=δi,jei and unit 1=∑iei1 = \sum_i e^i1=∑i​ei we have

dej=1⊗ej−ej⊗1=∑k(ek⊗ej−ej⊗ek)\begin{aligned} de^j &= 1\otimes e^j - e^j\otimes 1 \\ &= \sum_k \left(e^k\otimes e^j - e^j\otimes e^k\right)\end{aligned}dej​=1⊗ej−ej⊗1=k∑​(ek⊗ej−ej⊗ek)​

and

eidej=ei⊗ej−δi,jei⊗1=ei⊗ej−δi,j∑lei⊗el\begin{aligned} e^i de^j &= e^i\otimes e^j - \delta^{i,j} e^i\otimes 1 \\ &= e^i\otimes e^j - \delta^{i,j} \sum_l e^i\otimes e^l\end{aligned}eidej​=ei⊗ej−δi,jei⊗1=ei⊗ej−δi,jl∑​ei⊗el​

so unless you restrict to i≠ji\ne ji=j for some reason, then eideje^i de^jeidej is a combination of em⊗ene^m\otimes e^nem⊗en. However, if you "close off" the dangling differential on the right, you get

eidejek=(δj,k−δi,j)ei⊗ek.e^i de^j e^k = (\delta^{j,k} - \delta^{i,j}) e^i\otimes e^k.eidejek=(δj,k−δi,j)ei⊗ek.

We can read off a bunch of info from this, e.g. if i=j=ki=j=ki=j=k, we have

eideiei=0e^i de^i e^i = 0eideiei=0

so all three indices cannot be the same. Similarly, if none of the indices are the same, i.e. i≠ji\ne ji=j, j≠kj\ne kj=k and k≠ik\ne ik=i, then

eidejek=0e^i de^j e^k = 0eidejek=0

vansihes again. However, if two of the three indices are the same we have

eidejei=0e^i de^j e^i = 0eidejei=0

and

eidejej=−eideiej=(1−δi,j)ei⊗eje^i de^j e^j = -e^i de^i e^j = (1-\delta^{i,j}) e^i\otimes e^jeidejej=−eideiej=(1−δi,j)ei⊗ej

so any degree 1 element is a linear combination of ei⊗eke^i\otimes e^kei⊗ek where i≠ki\ne ki=k, i.e. linear combinations of eidejek.e^i de^j e^k.eidejek. In fact

eidej=∑keidejek.e^i de^j = \sum_k e^i de^j e^k.eidej=∑k​eidejek.

(I have more to say - including actual code - but this comment is already too long :sweat_smile:)

Eric Forgy said:

It is not a mathematical problem, but I prefer to not leave a differential exposed directly on either the left or right side like that though (but I get what you mean) so I'd say write linear combinations of elements like

x0dx1⋯dxnxn+1x_0 dx_1 \cdots dx_n x_{n+1}x0​dx1​⋯dxn​xn+1​ [typo fixed]

That's okay if you want it; just beware that two linear combinations of elements like this can be equal in highly nonobvious ways!

The great thing about linear combinations of elements like

x0dx1⋯dxnx_0 dx_1 \cdots dx_n x0​dx1​⋯dxn​

is that it's really easy to tell when they're equal. The only relations that hold are 'obvious' ones saying this expression is linear in each variable. Namely:

(cx0+c′x0′)dx1⋯dxn=cx0dx1⋯dxn+c′x0′dx1⋯dxn (c x_0 + c' x_0') dx_1 \cdots dx_n \quad =\quad c x_0 dx_1 \cdots dx_n \quad + \quad c' x_0' dx_1 \cdots dx_n (cx0​+c′x0′​)dx1​⋯dxn​=cx0​dx1​⋯dxn​+c′x0′​dx1​⋯dxn​

where c,c′c,c'c,c′ are numbers (elements of our field), and similarly

x0dx1⋯d(cxi+c′xi′)⋯dxn=cx0dx1⋯dxi⋯dxn+c′x0dx1⋯dxi′⋯dxn x_0 dx_1 \cdots d(c x_i + c' x'_i) \cdots dx_n \quad = \quad c x_0 dx_1 \cdots dx_i \cdots dx_n \quad +\quad c' x_0 dx_1 \cdots dx'_i \cdots dx_n x0​dx1​⋯d(cxi​+c′xi′​)⋯dxn​=cx0​dx1​⋯dxi​⋯dxn​+c′x0​dx1​⋯dxi′​⋯dxn​

and of course the consequences of these. But these are quite manageable.

So: if you have a basis of your algebra AAA, you get a basis of the free dga on AAA by taking elements like

x0dx1⋯dxn x_0 dx_1 \cdots dx_n x0​dx1​⋯dxn​

where each of the xix_ixi​ is chosen to be a basis element!

John Baez said:

That's okay if you want it; just beware that two linear combinations of elements like this can be equal in nonobvious ways!

Yes :blush:

When I am talking about generating the space, I think it is a little more intuitive to have that element on the right, but yeah, totally, when I compute stuff, I write all coefficients on one side or the other (and the choice can be interesting because degree 0 and degree 1 elements do not commute) :blush:

Btw, with f=∑if(i)eif = \sum_i f(i) e^if=∑i​f(i)ei, g=∑jg(j)ejg = \sum_j g(j) e^jg=∑j​g(j)ej and h=∑kh(k)ekh = \sum_k h(k) e^kh=∑k​h(k)ek, we have

f(dg)h=∑i,j,kf(i)g(j)h(k)eidejek=∑i,jf(i)[g(j)−g(i)]h(j)ei⊗ej\begin{aligned} f(dg)h &= \sum_{i,j,k} f(i) g(j) h(k) e^i de^j e^k \\ &= \sum_{i,j} f(i)\left[g(j)-g(i)\right] h(j) e^i\otimes e^j\end{aligned}f(dg)h​=i,j,k∑​f(i)g(j)h(k)eidejek=i,j∑​f(i)[g(j)−g(i)]h(j)ei⊗ej​

which explains why we think of ei⊗eje^i\otimes e^jei⊗ej (which I usually write ei,je^{i,j}ei,j) as (dual to) a directed edge.

Btw, I don't know what you're doing with these tensor products here, since you didn't explain it. One trick people commonly do is write

a1da2⋯dan a_1 d a_2 \cdots d a_n a1​da2​⋯dan​

as

a1⊗a2⊗⋯⊗an a_1 \otimes a_2 \otimes \cdots \otimes a_n a1​⊗a2​⊗⋯⊗an​

but it doesn't look like you're doing that.

since you didn't explain it

Yeah :sweat_smile: The tensor product is just usual tensor product of the respective vectors. 1 is vector with all "components" equal to 1, i.e.

1=∑iei.1 = \sum_i e^i.1=∑i​ei.

So if a∈Aa\in Aa∈A, then aaa is a vector

a=∑ia(i)eia = \sum_i a(i) e^ia=∑i​a(i)ei

so

1⊗a=(∑iei)⊗(∑ja(j)ej)=∑i,ja(j)ei⊗ej1\otimes a = \left(\sum_i e^i\right) \otimes \left(\sum_j a(j) e^j\right) = \sum_{i,j} a(j) e^i\otimes e^j1⊗a=(∑i​ei)⊗(∑j​a(j)ej)=∑i,j​a(j)ei⊗ej

is just the usual tensor product.

We do need to define a(b⊗c)a(b\otimes c)a(b⊗c) and (a⊗b)c(a\otimes b)c(a⊗b)c, but those are straightforward

a(b⊗c):=(ab)⊗ca(b\otimes c) := (ab)\otimes ca(b⊗c):=(ab)⊗c

and

(a⊗b)c:=a⊗(bc).(a\otimes b)c := a\otimes (bc).(a⊗b)c:=a⊗(bc).
Okay - but you're not telling me the thing I really need to know, which is the differential in terms of these tensor products. Like if I write a db dca\, db \, dcadbdc, what's that for you?
There's one standard convention where it's called a⊗b⊗ca \otimes b \otimes ca⊗b⊗c. You'll see this in lots of work on Hochschild and cyclic homology.
Here a,b,ca,b,ca,b,c are elements of our algebra AAA, not numbers.

The differential is

da=1⊗a−a⊗1.da = 1\otimes a - a\otimes 1.da=1⊗a−a⊗1.

See for example (1.24) of C&K.
Okay, great. That's a different convention. I guess that's pretty standard too!
I saw you write that but it just confused me.
So with this convention a db dca \, db \, dc adbdc turns into some big mess, but that's okay.
So C&K give you an explicit way to construct d:A0→A1d: A^0\to A^1d:A0→A1 and it says this. Unfortunately, the extension is not obvious to me :sweat_smile:
You extend it using the dga law d(xy)=(dx)y+x(dy)d(xy) = (dx)y + x(dy)d(xy)=(dx)y+x(dy).
This holds for any elements x,yx,yx,y in your dga.

I'd like to find a natural / minimal nontrivial definition of d:A1→A2d: A^1\to A^2d:A1→A2 such that

d(1⊗a)=d(a⊗1)d(1\otimes a) = d(a\otimes 1)d(1⊗a)=d(a⊗1)

so that

d2a=0.d^2a = 0.d2a=0.
You can just calculate it.

I have a notebook with pages of scribbles. No luck so far :sweat_smile:

But you inspired me. Let me try some things.
It's a calculation - no inspiration required, just follow the rules.
Yes sensei. I will try :blush:
Take anybody in A1A^1A1 and write it as a linear combination of products of guys like aaa and dbd bdb.
Thank you :heart: :raised_hands:
Yes. It seems so obvious now that you say it :sweat_smile:
Then hit it with ddd and use dga rules like d(adb)=dadbd(a db) = da db d(adb)=dadb
Yes
In fact, every reference on this stuff says it, but for some reason it didn't sink in until YOU said it, so thank you so much :pray:

I think when you're done you may have reinvented "the differential in the Hochschild cochain complex", but don't let that intimidate you... it's not really a matter of creativity, I think there's basically no free choice involved.
Yes
I don't understand something until I've reinvented it.
Good.
Thank you again so much :pray:

Sure! It's funny, I was working on this stuff all the time when I was a postdoc right out of grad school. I was convinced that noncommutative geometry held the keys to quantum gravity, and I was working on it in my own slow way when Connes started putting out papers on it, and then I had to understand those.
I eventually gave up trying to do quantum gravity this way, when loop quantum gravity came along.
I remember :blush: :+1:

To be honest, I'm still a little surprised there is not more work along these lines. Urs made the link between our paper and NCG pretty clear and the cool thing is that it is not only cool maths, it can be used directly to generate code for engineering applications.
So my homework is to try to tell what is d(1⊗a).d(1\otimes a).d(1⊗a).
Or better d(ei⊗ej).d(e^i\otimes e^j).d(ei⊗ej).
I got it. I knew the answer already, but was never able to reinvent it until now :+1:
So after 20+ years, I am still making slow but sure progress :nerd:
d(ei⊗ej)=1⊗ei⊗ej−ei⊗1⊗ej+ei⊗ej⊗1.d(e^i\otimes e^j) = 1\otimes e^i\otimes e^j - e^i\otimes 1\otimes e^j + e^i\otimes e^j\otimes 1.d(ei⊗ej)=1⊗ei⊗ej−ei⊗1⊗ej+ei⊗ej⊗1.
d(1⊗a)=d(a⊗1)=1⊗a⊗1  ⟹  d2a=0.d(1\otimes a) = d(a\otimes 1) = 1\otimes a\otimes 1 \implies d^2a = 0.d(1⊗a)=d(a⊗1)=1⊗a⊗1⟹d2a=0. :check:

So I think it is safe to say I finally understand the functor Alg→DGAlgAlg\to DGAlgAlg→DGAlg :tada:

Or, at least, if you give me a finite dimensional commutative algebra, I can construct a DGA, BUT, if I understand correctly, that DGA is "universal" for AAA. My next task is to understand an explicit way to construct a DGA that is not universal, i.e. the above gives

A→Ω~AA\to \tilde\Omega AA→Ω~A

so now I need to explicitly construct a map

Ω~A→ΩA.\tilde\Omega A \to \Omega A.Ω~A→ΩA.

The answer should morally be something like "forget some edges".
I think I got it!

I spent some more time on this, including working through

  • Bourbaki, Elements of Algebra III 10.10: UNIVERSAL PROBLEM FOR DERIVATIONS; NON-COMMUTATIVE CASE

It is very pretty :heart_eyes:

The idea is:

Give an algebra AAA and a product m:A⊗A→Am: A\otimes A\to Am:A⊗A→A, let Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1 denote ker(m)\mathsf{ker}(m)ker(m).

The derivation d~:A→Ω~1\tilde d: A\to\tilde\Omega^1d~:A→Ω~1 given by

d~:a↦1⊗a−a⊗1\tilde d: a\mapsto 1\otimes a - a\otimes 1d~:a↦1⊗a−a⊗1

generates Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1 as a left AAA-module (despite the fact Ω~1\tilde\Omega^1Ω~1 is an AAA-bimodule).

Now, if a⊗b∈Ω~1a\otimes b\in\tilde\Omega^1a⊗b∈Ω~1, then

a db=a⊗b−ab⊗1=a⊗b\begin{aligned} a \, db &= a\otimes b - ab\otimes 1 \\ &= a\otimes b\end{aligned}adb​=a⊗b−ab⊗1=a⊗b​

since ab=0ab = 0ab=0.

John Baez said:

So with this convention a db dca \, db \, dc adbdc turns into some big mess, but that's okay.

Actually, it isn't a big mess. It turns out

a db dc=a⊗b⊗ca \, db \, dc = a\otimes b\otimes cadbdc=a⊗b⊗c

if a⊗b,b⊗c∈Ω~1.a \otimes b, b\otimes c\in\tilde\Omega^1.a⊗b,b⊗c∈Ω~1. The point is that we don't take just any a,b∈Aa,b\in Aa,b∈A and form a dba \, dbadb. a⊗ba\otimes ba⊗b needs to be in Ω~1=ker(m).\tilde\Omega^1 = \mathsf{ker}(m).Ω~1=ker(m).

Bourbaki helped me understand why

d~:A→Ω~1\tilde d: A\to\tilde\Omega^1d~:A→Ω~1

is a "universal derivation".

If ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1\phi: \tilde\Omega^1\to\Omega^1ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1 is an AAA-bimodule morphism, then

d=ϕ∘d~:A→Ω1d = \phi\circ \tilde d: A\to\Omega^1d=ϕ∘d~:A→Ω1

is also a derivation.

Conversely, Bourbaki shows that given any derivation d:A→Ω1d: A\to\Omega^1d:A→Ω1, you get a unique AAA-bimodule morphism

ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1\phi: \tilde\Omega^1\to \Omega^1ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1

such that d=ϕ∘d~d = \phi\circ\tilde dd=ϕ∘d~ given by

ϕ:a⊗b↦a db.\phi: a\otimes b \mapsto a \, db.ϕ:a⊗b↦adb.

In this way, we see

Hom(A,A)(Ω~1,Ω1)≅DerK(A,Ω1).\mathsf{Hom}_{(A,A)}(\tilde\Omega^1,\Omega^1) \cong \mathsf{Der}_K(A,\Omega^1).Hom(A,A)​(Ω~1,Ω1)≅DerK​(A,Ω1).

It was painful to work through that, but worth it :blush: :muscle:

(w dx)⊗(y dz)↦(w dx)(y dz)=w (dx y) dz=w[d(xy)−x dy] dz=w d(xy) dz.\begin{aligned}(w\, dx)\otimes (y\, dz) \mapsto (w\, dx)(y\, dz) &= w\, (dx\, y)\, dz \\ &= w\left[d(xy) - x\, dy\right] \, dz \\ &= w\, d(xy)\, dz.\end{aligned}(wdx)⊗(ydz)↦(wdx)(ydz)​=w(dxy)dz=w[d(xy)−xdy]dz=wd(xy)dz.​

If AAA has basis elements eie^iei with product eiej=δi,jeie^i e^j = \delta^{i,j} e^ieiej=δi,jei and unit element 1=∑iei1 = \sum_i e^i1=∑i​ei, then

df=1⊗f−f⊗1=∑i,j[f(j)−f(i)]ei⊗ej\begin{aligned} df &= 1\otimes f - f\otimes 1 \\ &= \sum_{i,j} \left[f(j) - f(i)\right] e^i\otimes e^j \end{aligned}df​=1⊗f−f⊗1=i,j∑​[f(j)−f(i)]ei⊗ej​

which looks like the finite difference along a direct edge i→ji\to ji→j (think "fundamental theorem of calculus"). So we take this seriously and interpret ei⊗ej:G1→Ke^i\otimes e^j: \mathcal{G}^1\to Kei⊗ej:G1→K as "dual" edges

ei⊗ej(k,l)=δjiδlj.e^i\otimes e^j(k,l) = \delta^i_j \delta^j_l.ei⊗ej(k,l)=δji​δlj​.

Also, any α∈A⊗A\alpha\in A\otimes Aα∈A⊗A can be written in terms of basis elements as

α=∑i,jα(i,j)ei⊗ej\alpha = \sum_{i,j} \alpha(i,j) e^i\otimes e^jα=∑i,j​α(i,j)ei⊗ej

and we have

m(α)=∑iα(i,i)eim(\alpha) = \sum_i \alpha(i,i) e^im(α)=∑i​α(i,i)ei

so Ω~1:=ker(m)\tilde\Omega^1 := \mathsf{ker}(m)Ω~1:=ker(m) is the subbimodule with all "diagonal" elements α(i,i)\alpha(i,i)α(i,i) set to zero. This can be interpreted as a directed graph with no "loops".

Then let

G~=1⊗1=∑i,jei⊗ej\tilde G = 1\otimes 1 = \sum_{i,j} e^i\otimes e^jG~=1⊗1=∑i,j​ei⊗ej

i.e. the sum of all dual edges of a complete graph, and we have

d~f=1⊗f−f⊗1=(1⊗1)f−f(1⊗1)=G~f−fG~=[G~,f].\begin{aligned} \tilde df &= 1\otimes f - f\otimes 1 \\ &= (1\otimes 1) f - f (1\otimes 1) \\ &= \tilde G f - f\tilde G \\ &= [\tilde G, f].\end{aligned}d~f​=1⊗f−f⊗1=(1⊗1)f−f(1⊗1)=G~f−fG~=[G~,f].​

If we combine this with the results above from Bourbaki, then we can define

G=∑(i,j)∈G1ei⊗ejG = \sum_{(i,j)\in\mathcal{G}^1} e^i\otimes e^jG=∑(i,j)∈G1​ei⊗ej

where G1\mathcal{G}^1G1 is a subset of G0×G0\mathcal{G}^0\times\mathcal{G}^0G0×G0, i.e. (G0,G1,s,t:G1→G0)(\mathcal{G}^0,\mathcal{G}^1,s,t:\mathcal{G}^1\to\mathcal{G}^0)(G0,G1,s,t:G1→G0) is a directed graph with s(ei⊗ej)=eis(e^i\otimes e^j) = e^is(ei⊗ej)=ei and t(ei⊗ej)=ejt(e^i\otimes e^j) = e^jt(ei⊗ej)=ej and we have a new derivation d:A→Ω1d: A\to\Omega^1d:A→Ω1 given by

df=[G,f]df = [G,f]df=[G,f]

and a unique bimodule morphism ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1\phi: \tilde\Omega^1\to\Omega^1ϕ:Ω~1→Ω1 given by

ϕ(a⊗b)=adb\phi(a\otimes b) = a dbϕ(a⊗b)=adb

satisfying

d=ϕ∘d~.d = \phi\circ\tilde d.d=ϕ∘d~.

The graph operator G∈A⊗AG\in A\otimes AG∈A⊗A can be obtained from the "universal" (or "complete") graph operator G~=1⊗1\tilde G = 1\otimes 1G~=1⊗1 by setting some of the dual edges ei⊗eje^i\otimes e^jei⊗ej to zero.

This is still all "first order" though so I think I have a pretty good handle on how things work to first order. So I still need to get a similar grip on Ω~2.\tilde\Omega^2.Ω~2.

It is interesting to see that Grothendieck also defined his derivation as an adjoint, i.e. commutator, but it should be the graded commutator for higher orders.

So now we have a way to tie a directed graph G:X→Set\mathcal{G}: X\to\mathsf{Set}G:X→Set to a first-order differential calculus.

In particular, there is a "universal" graph G~\mathcal{\tilde G}G~​ with

G~1=G~0×G~0\mathcal{\tilde G}^1 = \mathcal{\tilde G}^0\times\mathcal{\tilde G}^0G~​1=G~​0×G~​0

giving the "complete" graph on the set G~0.\mathcal{\tilde G}^0.G~​0.

This is the "universal endospan in Set\mathsf{Set}Set" or the better, the "universal quiver in Set\mathsf{Set}Set". This extends (via free construction - I believe) to a "universal quiver in AlgK\mathsf{Alg}_KAlgK​", where

AlgK:=Mon(VectK)\mathsf{Alg}_K := \mathsf{Mon}(\mathsf{Vect}_K)AlgK​:=Mon(VectK​)

so I think the category I need to work in (at least up to this point) is actually a bicategory

Span(Alg).\mathsf{Span(Alg)}.Span(Alg).
